conclusion: Understanding the problem involves an ideal gas changing states from A to B to C with known pressure and volume values.
The p-V diagram has volume on the x-axis and pressure on the y-axis with points A, B, and C.
Each grid square represents 1 unit in both pressure and volume.
Point A: V_A = 6 x 10^-3 m³, P_A = 1 x 10^5 Pa.
Point B: V_B = 6 x 10^-3 m³, P_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa.
Point C: V_C = 3 x 10^-3 m³, P_C = 3 x 10^5 Pa.
From A to B: Volume constant, pressure increases from 1 to 2 x 10^5 Pa.
From B to C: Pressure increases from 2 to 3 x 10^5 Pa, volume decreases from 6 to 3 x 10^-3 m³.
Using the ideal gas law PV = nRT with constant n (moles).
Temperature at state A is 27°C, which is 300 K.
Using Charles' law for A to B: P_A/T_A = P_B/T_B.
Solving for T_B: T_B = (2 x 10^5 x 300) / (1 x 10^5) = 600 K.
From B to C, both pressure and volume change.
